name: Atlantic-Congo (> North-Central Atlantic)
1_tam_restrictions: seulement avec le préfixe N- de l’inaccompli

name: Atlantic-Congo (> Volta-Congo > Kwa)
1_comment: the first meaning is again. Check periphrastic constructions in Ameka 2008 (Aspect and modality in Ewe: A survey).

name: Atlantic-Congo (> Volta-Congo > Gur)
1_morphosyntactic_type_detailed: catenative verb (verb with an auxiliary status)

name: Atlantic-Congo (> Volta-Congo > East Bantu > Corridor Bantu)
Atlantic-Congo (> Volta-Congo > East Bantu > Southern Bantu-Makua)
1_adjacent_meanings: just, for a while, for a short time

name: Afro-Asiatic (> Semitic)
1_tam_restrictions: atelic, stative, multiplicative (="complex") predicates + telic (only resultative meaning)

name: Afro-Asiatic (> Berber)
1_comment: "indicates that the event is still relevant in the present"

name: Afro-Asiatic (> Chadic)
1_comment: seems to have some modal meaning and some special syntactic (linking) function. Almost all examples are a bit strange. See also Viljoen 2015: 70-71.

name: Afro-Asiatic (> Egyptian)
1_comment: the first meaning is again. There is also a Greek borrowing et(e)i, which predominantly functions as a syntactic linker (cf. Chadic), p. 248, 424

name: Mande
1_adjacent_meanings: progressive, contingent state, (with perfective - for a while)

name: Central Sudanic
1_morphosyntactic_type_detailed: verb taking as its complement a sentence with a nonverbal predicate and a missing subject
1_meaning_under_negation_comment: see ex. 175 ((b) 'Opi is not a teacher still.' (has ceased to be a teacher))
1_tam_restrictions: it seems that 'still' meaning appears only with statives, see ex. 188-189 for still in past

name: Nilotic
1_meaning_under_negation_comment: "when the element itself is negated, and the second verb form occurs in the affirmative, the former indicates 'no longer'. When the initial form occurs in the affirmative and the following verb is negated, the construction as a whole indicates 'not yet', see also 9.2.7.2-9.2.7.3
1_tam_restrictions: all examples are with the verb 'to be'
1_other_uses: before (e.g. before tomorrow, p. 360), + neg = before (while not yet) - section 9.2.7.2

name: Nubian
1_comment: many examples in other sections of the grammar

name: Surmic
1_comment: can't find any examples, see also dictionary

name: Songhay
1_comment: described only with negation as not yet

name: Koman
1_comment: can't find examples without negation; there is also an Arabic borrowing - lisa 'still'

name: Kuliak
1_comment: possible borrowing from Turkana "And the verb sár- is functionally quite similar to the Turkana auxiliary -rok- which Dimmendaal calls the “auxiliary of unexpected state of affairs” in the affirmative (1983:138) and the “unexpected negative perfective” in the negative (1983:457)." Maybe this is a contact influnce because Turkana is spoken almost in the same place
